item.link_title: MORGANS MUST: AUGUST IN SAN FRANCISCO
item.title: Family Genus The
item.intro_content: The cayenne pepper—also known as the Guinea spice,[1] cow-horn pepper, aleva, bird pepper,[2] or, especially in its powdered form, red pepper—is a hot chili pepper used to flavour dishesIt is red colored when ripened to maturity, but also eaten while still green It is a cultivar of Capsicum annuum related to bell peppers, jalapeños, paprika and othersThe Capsicum genus is in the nightshade family (Solanaceae)
item.article_content:
The cayenne pepper—also known as the Guinea spice,[1] cow-horn pepper, aleva, bird pepper,[2] or, especially in its powdered form, red pepper—is a hot chili pepper used to flavour dishes

The cayenne pepper—also known as the Guinea spice,[1] cow-horn pepper, aleva, bird pepper,[2] or, especially in its powdered form, red pepper—is a hot chili pepper used to flavour dishes

  • Cayenne Powder
  • Or Powder
  • In Whole
  • A Thin,

The Capsicum genus is in the nightshade family (Solanaceae)

It is generally rated at 30,000 to 50,000 Scoville units

It is a cultivar of Capsicum annuum related to bell peppers, jalapeños, paprika and othersIt is named for the city of Cayenne in French Guiana

item.link_title: MORGANS MUST: AUGUST IN LOS ANGELES
item.title: Scoville Units It
item.intro_content: The cayenne pepper—also known as the Guinea spice,[1] cow-horn pepper, aleva, bird pepper,[2] or, especially in its powdered form, red pepper—is a hot chili pepper used to flavour dishesIt is red colored when ripened to maturity, but also eaten while still green It is a cultivar of Capsicum annuum related to bell peppers, jalapeños, paprika and othersThe Capsicum genus is in the nightshade family (Solanaceae)
item.article_content:
It is red colored when ripened to maturity, but also eaten while still green

The fruits are generally dried and ground, or pulped and baked into cakes, which are then ground and sifted to make the powdered spice of the same name

  • Red Guinea
  • The Cow-horn
  • Form, To
  • Aleva, Red

It is also used as an herbal supplement, and was mentioned by Nicholas Culpeper in his Complete Herbal, 1653, as 'guinea pepper'[3] a misnomer for 'guiana pepper'

Cayenne is used in cooking spicy dishes, as a powder or in its whole form (such as in Korean, Sichuan and other Asian cuisine), or in a thin, vinegar-based sauce

It is a cultivar of Capsicum annuum related to bell peppers, jalapeños, paprika and othersIt is named for the city of Cayenne in French Guiana
